action.action-desc: Mr. Crawford (for himself, Mr. Golden of Maine, Mr. Westerman, Mr. Carbajal, Mr. LaHood, and Ms. Perez) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

form.official-title: To establish an apprenticeship program for commercial drivers under the age of 21, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Developing Responsible Individuals for a Vibrant Economy Act or the DRIVE-SAFE Act.

section.header: Apprenticeship program for commercial drivers under the age of 21

paragraph.text: The term apprentice means an employee under the age of 21 who holds a commercial driver’s license required to operate a class of vehicles described in part 383 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations.
The term commercial driver's license has the meaning given the term in section 31301 of title 49, United States Code.

The term commercial motor vehicle means a commercial motor vehicle that meets the definition under paragraph (1) or (4) of the definition of the term commercial motor vehicle in section 390.5 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations (as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act).
The term driving time has the meaning given the term in section 395.2 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations (as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act).
The term employee has the meaning given such term in section 31132 of title 49, United States Code.
The term employer has the meaning given such term in section 31132 of title 49, United States Code.
The term experienced driver means an individual who—

subparagraph.text: is not less than 26 years of age;
has held a commercial driver’s license for the 2-year period ending on the date on which the individual serves as an experienced driver under subsection (c)(3)(B);

has had no preventable accidents reportable to the Department of Transportation or pointed moving violations during the 1-year period ending on the date on which the individual serves as an experienced driver under subsection (c)(3)(B); and
has a minimum of 2 years of experience driving a commercial motor vehicle in interstate commerce.

paragraph.text: The term on-duty time has the meaning given the term in section 395.2 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations (as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act).
The term pointed moving violation means a violation that results in points being added to the license of a driver, or a similar comparable violation, as determined by the Secretary.
The term Secretary means the Secretary of Transportation.

drive a commercial motor vehicle in interstate commerce while taking part in the 120-hour probationary period under subsection (c)(1) or the 280-hour probationary period under subsection (c)(2), pursuant to an apprenticeship program established by an employer in accordance with this section; and
drive a commercial motor vehicle in interstate commerce after the apprentice completes an apprenticeship program described in paragraph (1).

subsection.text: An apprenticeship program referred to in subsection (b) is a program that consists of the following requirements:

subparagraph.text: The apprentice shall complete 120 hours of on-duty time, of which not less than 80 hours are driving time in a commercial motor vehicle.
In order to complete the 120-hour probationary period under subparagraph (A), an employer shall determine that the apprentice is competent in each of the following areas:

clause.text: Interstate, city traffic, rural 2-lane, and evening driving.
Logging and complying with rules relating to hours of service.

subparagraph.text: After completing the 120-hour probationary period under paragraph (1), the apprentice shall complete 280 hours of on-duty time, of which not less than 160 hours are driving time in a commercial motor vehicle.
In order to complete the 280-hour probationary period under subparagraph (A), an employer shall determine that the apprentice is competent in each of the following areas:

clause.text: Backing and maneuvering in close quarters.
Weighing loads, weight distribution, and sliding tandems.
Trip planning, truck routes, map reading, navigation, and permits.

paragraph.text: During the 120-hour probationary period under paragraph (1) and the 280-hour probationary period under paragraph (2)—

subparagraph.text: the apprentice may only drive a commercial motor vehicle that has—

clause.text: active braking collision mitigation systems; and

subparagraph.text: the apprentice shall be accompanied in the cab of the commercial motor vehicle by an experienced driver.

paragraph.text: The employer shall maintain records, in a manner required by the Secretary, relating to the satisfaction of the requirements of paragraphs (1)(B) and (2)(B) by the apprentice.

If the apprentice is involved in a preventable accident reportable to the Department of Transportation or a pointed moving violation while driving a commercial motor vehicle as part of an apprenticeship program described in this subsection, the apprentice shall undergo remediation and additional training until the apprentice can demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the employer, competence in each of the performance benchmarks described in paragraphs (1)(B) and (2)(B).
The apprentice shall be considered to have completed the apprenticeship program on the date on which the apprentice completes the 280-hour probationary period under paragraph (2).

subparagraph.text: Nothing in this Act prevents an employer from imposing additional requirements on an apprentice taking part in an apprenticeship program established pursuant to this section.
Nothing in this Act prevents an employer from requiring or installing additional technologies in a commercial motor vehicle in addition to the technologies described in paragraph (3)(A).

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall promulgate regulations to implement this Act.
Nothing in this Act exempts an apprentice from any requirement to hold a commercial driver’s license in order to operate a commercial motor vehicle.

An employer shall not knowingly allow, require, permit, or authorize a driver under the age of 21 to operate a commercial motor vehicle in interstate commerce unless the driver is participating in or has completed an apprenticeship program that meets the requirements of subsection (c).
